Festival di Jepang akhirnya putar film tentang budak seks zaman perang
04 Nov 2019, 15:22 by BBC


Patung "budak seks" di luar Kedutaan Besar Jepang di Seoul.

Festival film Jepang akhirnya memutar sebuah film dokumenter tentang perempuan yang dipaksa menjadi pekerja seks pada zaman perang, setelah sebelumnya membatalkan pemutaran, keputusan yang memicu kecaman.
Penyelenggara festival di Kawasaki tersebut menyatakan masalah keamanan terkait pemutaran film telah teratasi.
Puluhan ribu "budak seks" dari Asia, termasuk Indonesia, dipaksa bekerja di bordil militer Jepang.


Para penyintas perbudakan seks masa penjajahan Jepang yang terlupakan


Jepang diminta hentikan manipulasi jugun ianfu


Ganti rugi bagi budak seks tentara Jepang 'tak penuhi' kebutuhan korban dari Korea Selatan


Kelompok nasionalis Jepang menyangkal para perempuan ini dipaksa menjadi pekerja seks.
Permulaan tahun ini pameran tentang "budak seks" dipaksa ditutup selama dua bulan karena muncul ancaman akan dibakar.


Sri Sukanti salah satu warga Indonesia yang dipaksa menjadi "budak seks" militer Jepang.

Alasan dibalik perubahan
Keputusan tidak memutar film tersebut diubah setelah "banyak pihak menyatakan siap memberikan bantuan untuk mengatasi kekhawatiran keamanan", kata seorang anggota dewan pelaksana kepada kantor berita AFP.
Beberapa sutradara yang terlibat dalam festival film mengecam rencana untuk tidak memutar film.
Salah satunya bahkan menarik filmnya sendiri dari festival sebagai bentuk protes.
Film berjudul "Shusenjo: The Main Battleground of the Comfort Women Issue" sekarang dijadwalkan akan diputar pada hari terakhir festival.

https://youtu.be/OtNuze8mNUQ

Meskipun demikian, sebagian orang yang muncul pada film tersebut telah mengajukan tuntutan di Pengadilan Negeri Tokyo, meminta ganti rugi dan mendesak film tersebut tidak diputar.
Mereka mengatakan bersedia muncul di dokumenter tersebut karena berpikir ini adalah bagian dari penelitian dan bukannya dalam rangka pembuatan film, lapor Asahi Shimbun.


Perundingan budak seks dipercepat Jepang dan Korsel


Jepang tarik duta besarnya terkait patung 'budak seks' di Korea Selatan


Istilah 'budak seks' dianggap salah oleh koran Jepang


Siapakah para 'budak seks'?
Ahli sejarah memperkirakan 200.000 perempan dipaksa bekerja di berbagai bordil untuk melayani tentara Jepang.
Kebanyakan dari mereka berasal dari Korea, tetapi juga dari Indonesia, China, Filipina dan Taiwan.
Sejumlah kelompok nasionalis Jepang menyangkal pernyataaan tersebut. Mereka menegaskan tidak terdapat bukti tertulis bahwa militer Jepang memerintahkan perekrutan perempuan secara paksa.
Masalah budak seks merupakan salah satu pertikaian yang merusak hubungan Jepang dengan sejumlah negara tetangganya di Asia.


Tentara Jepang di Korea.

Tokyo menyatakan traktat 1965 yang memulihkan hubungan diplomatik dan pemberian bantuan keuangan Jepang lebih dari US$800 juta atau Rp11 triliun untuk Korea Selatan telah menyelesaikan masalah.
Tahun 2015, Jepang menandatangani persetujuan dengan Korea Selatan untuk mengatasi persoalan ini.
Jepang meminta maaf dan berjanji membayar satu miliar yen atau Rp129 miliar -- jumlah yang diminta Korea Selatan -- bagi para korban.
Sejumlah pengecamnya mengatakan persetujuan dicapai tanpa berkonsultasi dengan para korban.


Sri Sukanti dengan suaminya, Muhamad Sidik, di rumah petak di Salatiga, Jawa Tengah.

Perempuan Indonesia juga dipaksa
Di Indonesia, perempuan dari Jawa dibawa ke garis depan peperangan, seperti di Kalimantan, Sulawesi, bahkan juga Maluku, termasuk di Pulau Buru.
Salah satunya adalah Sri Sukanti (80-an tahun) yang baru berusia sembilan tahun ketika dibawa tentara Jepang ke Gedung Papak, Purwodadi, Jawa Tengah.
"Wah ayah saya semaput-semaput (pingsan) saya dibawa dikira mau dibunuh. Terus ada lagi teman saya sekolah, dikira mau dibunuh. 'Jangan, saya saja, saya saja'," ungkap Sri.


Tentara sekutu juga memperkosa, kata Hashimoto


Kesaksian para penyintas ianfu di masa penjajahan Jepang


Perempuan penghibur 'lumrah' dalam perang


Di Indonesia, lewat badan bentukan Jepang Asia Women Fund, diberikan dana sebesar 380 juta yen (sekitar Rp24 milliar dengan kurs saat itu) melalui Kementerian Sosial secara bertahap selama 10 tahun untuk membangun fasilitas 235 panti jompo di seluruh daerah.
Sri Sukanti mengaku pernah mendapatkan dana bantuan dari Kementerian Sosial selama sekitar tiga bulan pada tahun 2011.

Festivals in Japan finally play films about wartime sex slaves
Nov 04 2019, 15:22 by BBC


A "sex slave" statue outside the Japanese Embassy in Seoul.

The Japanese film festival finally screened a documentary about women forced into sex work during the war, having previously canceled screenings, a decision that sparked criticism.
The organizer of the festival in Kawasaki said security issues related to the screening had been resolved.
Tens of thousands of "sex slaves" from Asia, including Indonesia, were forced to work in Japanese military brothels.


The survivors of forgotten sex slavery during the Japanese occupation


Japan was asked to stop manipulation of jugun ianfu


Compensation for Japanese military sex slaves 'did not meet' the needs of victims from South Korea


Japanese nationalists deny these women are forced into sex work.
Earlier this year an exhibition about "sex slaves" was forced to close for two months because of the threat of burning.


Sri Sukanti is an Indonesian citizen who was forced to become a "sex slave" of the Japanese military.

The reason behind the change
The decision not to screen the film was changed after "many said they were ready to provide assistance to overcome security concerns," an executive board member told AFP.
Some directors involved in film festivals condemned plans not to show films.
One of them even pulled his own film from the festival as a form of protest.
The film titled "Shusenjo: The Main Battleground of the Comfort Women Issue" is now scheduled to be screened on the last day of the festival.

https://youtu.be/OtNuze8mNUQ

However, some people who appeared on the film had filed a lawsuit in the Tokyo District Court, asking for compensation and urging the film not be screened.
They said they were willing to appear in the documentary because they thought this was part of the research and not in the context of filmmaking, Asahi Shimbun reported.


Japan and South Korea accelerated sex slave talks


Japan pulls its ambassador over the statue of 'sex slaves' in South Korea


The term 'sex slave' is considered wrong by Japanese newspapers


Who are the 'sex slaves'?
Historians estimate 200,000 women were forced to work in various brothels to serve the Japanese army.
Most of them are from Korea, but also from Indonesia, China, the Philippines and Taiwan.
A number of Japanese nationalist groups denied the statement. They stressed that there was no written evidence that the Japanese military ordered the recruitment of women by force.
The issue of sex slaves is one of the conflicts that have damaged Japan's relations with a number of neighboring countries in Asia.


Japanese army in Korea.

Tokyo said the 1965 treaty which restored diplomatic relations and provided Japanese financial assistance of more than US $ 800 million or Rp11 trillion for South Korea had resolved the problem.
In 2015, Japan signed an agreement with South Korea to resolve this issue.
Japan apologized and promised to pay one billion yen, or the amount requested by South Korea for the victims.
Some critics say agreement was reached without consulting the victims.


Sri Sukanti with her husband, Muhamad Sidik, in a tenement in Salatiga, Central Java.

Indonesian women are also forced
In Indonesia, women from Java were brought to the forefront of warfare, such as in Kalimantan, Sulawesi, and even Maluku, including on Buru Island.
One of them is Sri Sukanti (80s) who was only nine years old when the Japanese were brought to the Papak Building, Purwodadi, Central Java.
"Wow, my father was in a state of collapse (fainting). I was taken away as if I wanted to be killed. Then there were more of my friends from school, thought they were going to be killed.


Allied forces also raped, said Hashimoto


Testimony of survivors of ianfu during the Japanese occupation


Comfort women are 'common' in war


In Indonesia, through a body formed by the Japan Asia Women Fund, 380 million yen (about Rp. 24 billion at the current exchange rate) was provided through the Ministry of Social Affairs in stages over 10 years to build 235 nursing home facilities throughout the region.
Sri Sukanti claimed to have received funding from the Ministry of Social Affairs for around three months in 2011.
